Blurb
Overview
Students will learn how to apply and deepen their knowledge of biochemistry and allied structural biology, biotechnology molecular and systems biology. In doing so they will gain the understanding that they have the underlying knowledge and skills required to understand and tackle any work-related scenario.

The module will be taught through a small number of lectures that provide orientation to the students, workshops, and small group tutorials. The workshops allow students to work collectively and to share their work, thus creating a resource for themselves, in the context of the two assessments. In the first Cycle, students will study examples of science communication within Biochemistry to understand what are the key elements that determine a successful piece and practice collectively writing a lay summary. In the second Cycle, students will, as individuals, act as consultants to apply their Biochemistry knowledge and deepen it where necessary in the context of a ‘product request’ scenario.

The first assessment will be a Science-Communication piece with an infographic explaining in lay terms a recent impactful development in the field, as one might find in a broadsheet, New Scientist, Ars Technica, or a company showcase. The second assessment will be a flash talk and/or a poster. The poster will describe the technical aspects of the steps or pipeline required to deliver the product defined in the chosen scenario.
Educational Aims
• To enhance the students' ability to identify, apply, critically evaluate, and interpret their biochemical knowledge to solve complex problems.
• To provide students with frameworks that allow them to efficiently deepen their knowledge in response to a new challenge.
• To use workshops and group tutorials to provide students with support in their self-learning.
• To develop the students' science presentation skills in various formats and to various target audiences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module provides students with the opportunity to showcase and extend their knowledge of biochemistry and allied disciplines in the context of explaining a recent commercially relevant development and to develop a scientifically and commercially credible pipeline to deliver a product of relevance to medicines, materials, biotechnology or education. The module is taught through workshops, tutorials, a small number of lectures and guided self-learning.
The module has 2 assessments. The first assessment will be a Science-Communication piece with an infographic explaining in lay terms a recent impactful development in the field, as one might find in a broadsheet, New Scientist, Ars Technica, or a company showcase. The second assessment will be a flash talk and/or a poster. The poster will describe the technical aspects of the steps or pipeline required to deliver the product defined in the chosen scenario.
Outline Syllabus
1. Science communication

Science is integral to society and each shape and transforms the other through their communication. Students will explore examples of typical science communication to understand their target audience and their value. They will also examine and analyse the importance of infographics or other forms of visual communication and tools to produce them.

2. Applying biochemical knowledge/techniques to solve real world problems

Using different real world problems/ grand challenges, students will be asked to explain which/how biochemical techniques are used to solve them. This will require application of the knowledge acquired in their programme - applied biochemistry.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught by a series of lectures, workshops and tutorials. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, enquiry-based learning, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence. Furthermore, workshops and tutorials allow the knowledge/concepts presented in the theory-delivery to be explored and applied in small groups.

Teaching Method 1 – Lectures
Description: Interactive sessions to include discussions
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 –Workshops
Description: Analysis of material pertaining to upcoming assessment and strategies required to credibly develop a pipeline to a product.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 – Tutorials
Description: Group discussion of the underlying science in which the staff member is an expert researcher in different areas of biochemistry.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research connected teaching: Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists on key areas of active commercial research and development to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and that students learn the process of research and inquiry and product development.

Active Learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and develop their own syntheses and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignments.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS and students will be supported to use some computational biology approaches to apply the material.

Global Citizenship: Discussion between students and staff in lectures and workshops give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) being a mixture of case-based short answer and essay style assessments. Students complete:

Assessment 1 (40%) will be a Science-Communication piece with an infographic explaining in lay terms a recent impactful development in the field, as one might find in a broadsheet, New Scientist, Ars Technica, or a company showcase.

Assessment 2 (60%) will be a flash talk and/or a poster. The poster will describe the technical aspects of the steps or pipeline required to deliver the product defined in the chosen scenario.

Reassessment strategy: Resits may take a different format as the original assessment. When similar, it will focus on a different topic on the syllabus. Resits will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 40%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
Students will learn how to apply and deepen their knowledge of biochemistry and allied structural biology, biotechnology molecular and systems biology. In doing so they will gain the understanding that they have the underlying knowledge and skills required to understand and tackle any work-related scenario.

The module will be taught through a small number of lectures that provide orientation to the students, workshops, and small group tutorials. The workshops allow students to work collectively and to share their work, thus creating a resource for themselves, in the context of the two assessments. In the first Cycle, students will study examples of science communication within Biochemistry to understand what are the key elements that determine a successful piece and practice collectively writing a lay summary. In the second Cycle, students will, as individuals, act as consultants to apply their Biochemistry knowledge and deepen it where necessary in the context of a ‘product request’ scenario.

The first assessment will be a Science-Communication piece with an infographic explaining in lay terms a recent impactful development in the field, as one might find in a broadsheet, New Scientist, Ars Technica, or a company showcase. The second assessment will be a flash talk and/or a poster. The poster will describe the technical aspects of the steps or pipeline required to deliver the product defined in the chosen scenario.
Educational Aims
• To enhance the students' ability to identify, apply, critically evaluate, and interpret their biochemical knowledge to solve complex problems.
• To provide students with frameworks that allow them to efficiently deepen their knowledge in response to a new challenge.
• To use workshops and group tutorials to provide students with support in their self-learning.
• To develop the students' science presentation skills in various formats and to various target audiences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module provides students with the opportunity to showcase and extend their knowledge of biochemistry and allied disciplines in the context of explaining a recent commercially relevant development and to develop a scientifically and commercially credible pipeline to deliver a product of relevance to medicines, materials, biotechnology or education. The module is taught through workshops, tutorials, a small number of lectures and guided self-learning.
The module has 2 assessments. The first assessment will be a Science-Communication piece with an infographic explaining in lay terms a recent impactful development in the field, as one might find in a broadsheet, New Scientist, Ars Technica, or a company showcase. The second assessment will be a flash talk and/or a poster. The poster will describe the technical aspects of the steps or pipeline required to deliver the product defined in the chosen scenario.
Outline Syllabus
1. Science communication

Science is integral to society and each shape and transforms the other through their communication. Students will explore examples of typical science communication to understand their target audience and their value. They will also examine and analyse the importance of infographics or other forms of visual communication and tools to produce them.

2. Applying biochemical knowledge/techniques to solve real world problems

Using different real world problems/ grand challenges, students will be asked to explain which/how biochemical techniques are used to solve them. This will require application of the knowledge acquired in their programme - applied biochemistry.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught by a series of lectures, workshops and tutorials. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, enquiry-based learning, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence. Furthermore, workshops and tutorials allow the knowledge/concepts presented in the theory-delivery to be explored and applied in small groups.

Teaching Method 1 – Lectures
Description: Interactive sessions to include discussions
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 –Workshops
Description: Analysis of material pertaining to upcoming assessment and strategies required to credibly develop a pipeline to a product.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 – Tutorials
Description: Group discussion of the underlying science in which the staff member is an expert researcher in different areas of biochemistry.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research connected teaching: Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists on key areas of active commercial research and development to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and that students learn the process of research and inquiry and product development.

Active Learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and develop their own syntheses and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignments.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS and students will be supported to use some computational biology approaches to apply the material.

Global Citizenship: Discussion between students and staff in lectures and workshops give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) being a mixture of case-based short answer and essay style assessments. Students complete:

Assessment 1 (40%) will be a Science-Communication piece with an infographic explaining in lay terms a recent impactful development in the field, as one might find in a broadsheet, New Scientist, Ars Technica, or a company showcase.

Assessment 2 (60%) will be a flash talk and/or a poster. The poster will describe the technical aspects of the steps or pipeline required to deliver the product defined in the chosen scenario.

Reassessment strategy: Resits may take a different format as the original assessment. When similar, it will focus on a different topic on the syllabus. Resits will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 40%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

In the first Cycle, students will study examples of science communication within Biochemistry to understand what are the key elements that determine a successful piece and practice collectively writing a lay summary. In the second Cycle, students will, as individuals, act as consultants to apply their Biochemistry knowledge and deepen it where necessary in the context of a ‘product request’ scenario.

The first assessment will be a Science-Communication piece with an infographic explaining in lay terms a recent impactful development in the field, as one might find in a broadsheet, New Scientist, Ars Technica, or a company showcase. The second assessment will be a flash talk and/or a poster. The poster will describe the technical aspects of the steps or pipeline required to deliver the product defined in the chosen scenario.
Educational Aims
• To enhance the students' ability to identify, apply, critically evaluate, and interpret their biochemical knowledge to solve complex problems.
• To provide students with frameworks that allow them to efficiently deepen their knowledge in response to a new challenge.
• To use workshops and group tutorials to provide students with support in their self-learning.
• To develop the students' science presentation skills in various formats and to various target audiences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module provides students with the opportunity to showcase and extend their knowledge of biochemistry and allied disciplines in the context of explaining a recent commercially relevant development and to develop a scientifically and commercially credible pipeline to deliver a product of relevance to medicines, materials, biotechnology or education. The module is taught through workshops, tutorials, a small number of lectures and guided self-learning.
The module has 2 assessments. The first assessment will be a Science-Communication piece with an infographic explaining in lay terms a recent impactful development in the field, as one might find in a broadsheet, New Scientist, Ars Technica, or a company showcase. The second assessment will be a flash talk and/or a poster. The poster will describe the technical aspects of the steps or pipeline required to deliver the product defined in the chosen scenario.
Outline Syllabus
1. Science communication

Science is integral to society and each shape and transforms the other through their communication. Students will explore examples of typical science communication to understand their target audience and their value. They will also examine and analyse the importance of infographics or other forms of visual communication and tools to produce them.

2. Applying biochemical knowledge/techniques to solve real world problems

Using different real world problems/ grand challenges, students will be asked to explain which/how biochemical techniques are used to solve them. This will require application of the knowledge acquired in their programme - applied biochemistry.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught by a series of lectures, workshops and tutorials. Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, enquiry-based learning, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence. Furthermore, workshops and tutorials allow the knowledge/concepts presented in the theory-delivery to be explored and applied in small groups.

Teaching Method 1 – Lectures
Description: Interactive sessions to include discussions
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 –Workshops
Description: Analysis of material pertaining to upcoming assessment and strategies required to credibly develop a pipeline to a product.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 – Tutorials
Description: Group discussion of the underlying science in which the staff member is an expert researcher in different areas of biochemistry.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research connected teaching: Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists on key areas of active commercial research and development to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and that students learn the process of research and inquiry and product development.

Active Learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and develop their own syntheses and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignments.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS and students will be supported to use some computational biology approaches to apply the material.

Global Citizenship: Discussion between students and staff in lectures and workshops give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) being a mixture of case-based short answer and essay style assessments. Students complete:

Assessment 1 (40%) will be a Science-Communication piece with an infographic explaining in lay terms a recent impactful development in the field, as one might find in a broadsheet, New Scientist, Ars Technica, or a company showcase.

Assessment 2 (60%) will be a flash talk and/or a poster. The poster will describe the technical aspects of the steps or pipeline required to deliver the product defined in the chosen scenario.

Reassessment strategy: Resits may take a different format as the original assessment. When similar, it will focus on a different topic on the syllabus. Resits will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 40%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
